Let\'s start with four basic letters of the Koine Greek alphabet. Take time to learn the shapes, sounds, and both uppercase and lowercase forms.
Great progress! Now let\'s continue with four more letters, vowels and consonants, very frequently used in Koine.
You\'re advancing well! This batch introduces four more consonants that appear frequently in Koine texts.
Let\'s learn four more letters. Notice sigma has different forms depending on its position in a word.
These four letters include important vowels that will help you read many more Koine words.
Congratulations on reaching the final letters! These complete your knowledge of the Koine alphabet.
Diphthongs are combinations of two vowels that form a single sound. These I-diphthongs combine various vowels with iota.
These U-diphthongs combine vowels with upsilon to create distinct sounds.
Improper diphthongs use an iota subscript beneath a vowel. They\'re pronounced as a single vowel sound, with the iota being silent.
Breathing marks appear on vowels at the beginning of words and indicate whether to add an \'h\' sound. Every Koine word that begins with a vowel must have a breathing mark.
There are three kinds of accents in Koine: acute (´), grave (`), and circumflex (῀). Accents are placed above a vowel and help with word pronunciation.
